Title: Creating contexts for talking and listening where older people feel comfortable and respected
Source: Being with Older People: A Systemic Approach
Abstract: © 2010 to Glenda Fredman, Eleanor Anderson, and Joshua Stott for the edited collection, and to the individual authors for their contributions.This chapter explores for talking and listening with older people where they feel comfortable and respected. It focuses on initial meetings, outlining steps with the older person and creating the sorts of therapeutic relationships where people feel heard and able to talk openly. The chapter explains that older people hear the words they have used fed back or summarized to them, they feel heard and understood. Hearing their own words also makes them reassess and sometimes change what they originally said. In this way, they are taking an observer perspective to themselves and are able to reflect on and evaluate their own perhaps previously taken for granted talk. The chapter also adopts a stance of “curiosity” to develop conversations, holding the view that there is not one explanation for clients’ situations, but, rather, that there are a multiplicity of possible explanations and understandings.
